title: Takizawa, Iwate
text:
is a <a href="Cities%20of%20Japan">city</a> located in <a href="Iwate%20Prefecture">Iwate Prefecture</a>, <a href="Japan">Japan</a>. , the city had an estimated <a href="population">population</a> of 55,325 in 23,270 households, and a <a href="population%20density">population density</a> of 300 persons per km2. The total area of the city is .
Geography.
Takizawa is located in central Iwate Prefecture, bordered to the north and west by the <a href="Mount%20Iwate">Iwate Mountains</a>, and the <a href="Kitakami%20River">Kitakami River</a> to the east and the Shizukuishi River to the south.
Neighboring municipalities.
Iwate Prefecture
Climate.
Takizawa has a cold <a href="humid%20continental%20climate">humid continental climate</a> (Köppen "Dfa") characterized by mild summers and cold winters with heavy snowfall. The average annual temperature in Takizawa is 9.5 °C. The average annual rainfall is 1386 mm with September as the wettest month and February as the driest month. The temperatures are highest on average in August, at around 23.3 °C, and lowest in January, at around -3.3 °C.
Demographics.
Per Japanese census data, the population of Takizawa has grown rapidly over the past 50 years.
History.
The area of present-day Takizawa was part of ancient <a href="Mutsu%20Province">Mutsu Province</a>. During the <a href="Heian%20period">Heian period</a>, it was ruled by the <a href="Abe%20clan">Abe clan</a>. During the <a href="Sengoku%20period">Sengoku period</a>, the area came under the control of the <a href="Nambu%20clan">Nambu clan</a> during the <a href="Edo%20period">Edo period</a>, who ruled <a href="Morioka%20Domain">Morioka Domain</a> under the <a href="Tokugawa%20shogunate">Tokugawa shogunate</a>.
In the <a href="Meiji%20period">Meiji period</a>, the village of Takizawa was established within <a href="Iwate%20District%2C%20Iwate">Iwate District</a> on April 1, 1889, with the establishment of the modern municipalities system. Takizawa was promoted directly from a village to a city on January 1, 2014.
Government.
Takizawa has a <a href="mayor-council">mayor-council</a> form of government with a directly elected mayor and a <a href="unicameral">unicameral</a> city legislature of 18 members. Takizawa, together with the town of Shizukuishi, contributes three seats to the Iwate Prefectural legislature. In terms of national politics, the city is part of <a href="Iwate%202nd%20district">Iwate 2nd district</a> of the <a href="House%20of%20Representatives%20of%20Japan">lower house</a> of the <a href="Diet%20of%20Japan">Diet of Japan</a>.
Economy.
Takizawa is a <a href="bedroom%20community">bedroom community</a> for Morioka, and a center for many institutions of higher education. Agriculture still plays an important role in the local economy, with Takizawa known for its summer watermelon and fall apples.
Education.
Primary and secondary education.
Takizawa has nine public elementary schools, eight of which are operated by the city government, and one of which is operated by the Morioka city government, although physically located within Takizawa. There are likewise seven public middle schools, six of which are operated by the city government and one of which is operated by the Morioka city government. There are two public high schools operated by the Iwate Prefectural Board of Education. There is also a special education school for the handicapped operated by the prefectural government.
